Crews searching the waters off the coast of Brazil today found more debris from the crash of Air France flight 447.
The Airbus jet carried 228 people when it disappeared Monday on its way from Rio de Janeiro to Paris.
Investigators know the plane encountered violent storms and that automated systems reported electrical problems, but exactly what happened and why remain mysteries.
The black box recorders that could provide answers are believed to lie somewhere amid a rugged range of underwater mountains as much as two miles below the surface.
Recovery experts say it will be a tremendous challenge, and the families of passengers of flight 447 may never know what happened to their loved ones.

Joining us now is John Hansman, Jr., who directs the International Center for Air Transportation at MIT.
He's an expert in air transportation and safety.
And thanks very much for being with us today.
Professor JOHN HANSMAN, Jr. (Director, International Center for Air Transportation, MIT): Happy to be here.
and at this point, do you think we're ever likely to find out what happened to this flight?
Yeah, I think we're going to figure it out.
Even if we don't recover the black boxes, I think there will be significant clues in those detailed maintenance records that were sent back.
So I think we'll be able to piece together at least reasonable hypotheses what happened.
The detailed maintenance records - you mean the electrical alerts?
Yeah.
This airplane was equipped with a ACARS reporting system, which basically automatically sent maintenance reports of problems onboard the airplane.
So, once we get - I haven't seen the details of those, but there were apparently 10 messages.
I think by looking at those in detail, we'll be able to figure out which systems on the airplane were failing, and in what order.
That information will be useful in at least putting together a hypothesis as to what could have been happening.
And will more information be gleaned if some of that debris can be recovered?
Absolutely.
The debris will give significant information.
So, for example, if any of the debris is burned, you would know that there was a fire.
By the location of the debris, it will give you some insight as to whether the airplane was together when it hit.
Unfortunately, nobody got there for a couple of days, so it had spread out.
So it's not as useful as if we've gotten there right away.
And the black boxes, two miles beneath the surface in apparently extremely rugged terrain.
This is - they only beam their beacons for about 30 days.
That's going to be hard.
Yeah.
This is going to be a very tough recovery in the black boxes.
As you noted, the black boxes give off sonar pings for about 30 days.
So, if they can get recovery vehicles to the area quickly enough, they'll - and can locate the black boxes, there is a chance that they can recover them.
If they don't do it, it's going to be a very hard search in the bottom of that deep ocean.

There's a few things that I think people just have a hard time understanding about this particular incident, one of which, yes, violent storms, but modern aircraft fly into thunderstorms all the time.
Sure.
We normally don't fly into thunderstorms.
We normally fly around them.
Modern aircraft are equipped with weather radar, which we use to pick our way even when there's areas of severe storms.
And even if you do go into a storm, the airplanes are designed to be strong enough to take the turbulence load.
They are metalized, so there shouldn't be a problem with lightning.
If you are hit by hail, for example, that can be a problem.
It can cause some damage to the airplane, but the airplane should stay airworthy and should be able to fly.
So it may be that the storms are related to what happened, but the storms in and of themselves should not have caused the airplane to come down.
Another thing people find hard to understand, why couldn't the pilots - there was no time to radio a mayday?
When you're out over the ocean, when you're offshore, you can't use the same radio that you use when you're over land masses.
So, over land masses, we use what we call VHF radio, which is line-of-sight.
And when you're in that situation, you can just pick up the radio and call quickly.
Over the oceans, you use what we call high-frequency radio.
It's short wave radio.
And it's literally like going back to the 1940s where you have to tune the radio, and you're basically bouncing the signals off the ionosphere.
As a result, pilots don't normally listen to the radio full-time.
They only use it for their check-ins every 600 miles or so.
